greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of partitions of n having exactly k doubletons (n>=0, k>=0). By a doubleton in a partition we mean an occurrence of a part exactly twice (the partition [4,(3,3),2,2,2,(1,1)] has two doubletons, shown between parentheses).
comment: Apparently, rows n with p(p+1)<=n<(p+1)(p+2) have at most p+1 terms. Row sums are the partition numbers (A000041). T(n,0)=A116645(n). Sum(k*T(n,k),k>=0)=A116646(n).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..614, flattened
example: T(6,2) = 1 because [2,2,1,1] is the only partition of 6 with 2 doubletons.
maple: g:=product(1+x^j+t*x^(2*j)+x^(3*j)/(1-x^j),j=1..35): gser:=simplify(series(g,x=0,35)): P[0]:=1: for n from 1 to 24 do P[n]:=coeff(gser,x^n) od: for n from 0 to 24 do seq(coeff(P[n],t,j),j=0..degree(P[n])) od; # sequence given in triangular form
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 20 2006
